name: Háteigsvegur 59
subtitle: Iceland's circular social housing - 53% CO2 reduction at conventional cost
data_source: Reykjavík City + BM Vallá + Hringvangur documentation

executive_summary.headline: 53% CO2 reduction with 20% reused/surplus materials - proving circular construction achievable at conventional cost for social housing
key_achievements: 53% CO2 reduction vs reference building (initial target 30%)
39% lower-carbon Berglind Plús concrete with recycled aggregate
Stone tiles donated from Smiðja Parliament project
Yakisugi/Shou Sugi Ban timber cladding (chemical-free, cheaper than metal)
Built within conventional cost framework (~530 million ISK)
Mies van der Rohe Award 2026 nomination
executive_summary.why_flagship: Háteigsvegur 59 is Iceland's most comprehensively documented circular building with verified LCA, LCC, and detailed material sourcing. It demonstrates that 53% CO2 reduction is achievable within conventional social housing budgets through strategic partnerships and creative material sourcing.
executive_summary.why_tier: Completeness score 88/100 (Grade A). Full LCA verification, detailed cost data, and extensive documentation from multiple sources including Reykjavík City official announcements.

budget.note: Within conventional cost framework despite circular approach

suppliers.name: SSJ Steinsmiðja / Grafa og grjót
suppliers.contribution: Stone tiles from Smiðja Parliament project

materials.description: Berglind Plús low-carbon concrete with crushed surplus stone tiles as aggregate
materials.donor_source: Surplus stone tiles from construction projects

materials.description: Composite windows: 6 reclaimed + 7 new units assembled together
Yakisugi/Shou Sugi Ban heat-treated surplus timber (no chemical impregnation)
Interior stone tiles reused from Smiðja Parliament project
Interior walls from flexible plywood previously used as formwork

overall.comparison_basis: Reference building, verified by VSÓ LCA at completion

awards.name: EU Prize for Contemporary Architecture - Mies van der Rohe Award

cost_comparison.innovation: Yakisugi cladding cheaper than corrugated metal

key_insights: 53% CO2 reduction achievable at conventional cost
Yakisugi cladding cheaper AND more sustainable than metal
Stone material flows between projects demonstrate circular ecosystem
success_factors: Local partner network (Húsasmiðjan, Gluggagerðin, BM Vallá)
Flexible design accepting materials found during construction
Askur Mannvirkjasjóður funding for 40% CO2 target support
challenges: Iterative sourcing - materials found during construction, not specified in advance
Multiple CO2 reduction figures reported (30-59%) due to different baselines

sources.name: BM Vallá - Sustainable Housing Case Study

narrative.driver: Félagsbústaðir wanted to demonstrate circular construction achievable within conventional cost/time for social housing.
narrative.approach: LCA+LCC from design. Partner network for surplus materials. Berglind Plús low-carbon concrete. Yakisugi cladding. Stone from Smiðja project demonstrates emerging Icelandic circular ecosystem.
narrative.significance: 53% CO2 reduction at conventional cost for social housing. Template for Icelandic circular construction.
narrative.legacy: Græna skóflan Award 2025. Mies nomination 2026. Model for future Félagsbústaðir projects.
